BookInfo.BookSubTitle: Towards Chemical Accuracy for Chemistry of Main Group Elements

ChapterInfo.ChapterTitle: A New Generation of Doubly Hybrid Density Functionals (DHDFs)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Doubly hybrid density functionals (DHDFs) present a new generation of density functionals, which not only enfold a nonlocal orbital-dependent component (i.e., the Hartree-Fock-like exchange) in the exchange part, but also incorporate the information of unoccupied orbitals (i.e., the second-order perturbative correlation) in the correlation part. Different types of DHDFs have been proposed according to different philosophies. They could be empirical as multicoefficient methods to allow the mixing of wavefunction-based methods with the hybrid density functional methods in order to achieve a good compromise of accuracy, cost, and ease of use for practical calculations, or they have their roots in multideterminant extension of the Kohn-Sham scheme or Görling–Levy’s coupling-constant perturbative theory. In this chapter, we first introduce a classification of the current DHDFs (Sect. 2.1). We then, in Sect. 2.2, discuss the Levy constrained search approach and adiabatic connection formalism, which provide a formal route that the exchange-correlation functional can be pursued. Finally, the underlying physics for the B2PLYP-type DHDFs and the XYG3-type DHDFs is explored in Sects. 2.3 and 2.4, respectively.

Section1.Heading: Classification of Current DHDFs
Section1.Para:
While the fourth rung functionals introduce nonlocality into the exchange functional by using a HF(Hartree-Fock)-like exchange
$$ E_{x}^{\rm HF} $$ (see Eq. 1.67
), a simple combination of
$$ E_{x}^{\rm HF} $$ with a local or semilocal correlation functional
$$ E_{c}^{\rm{DFA}} $$ was unsuccessful (Eq. 1.68
). There is a need to introduce nonlocality into the correlation functional so as to make a good match within
$$ E_{\rm xc} $$ . This calls for the fifth rung functionals that include also the information of unoccupied orbitals [1, 2]. There are several ways that the fifth rung functionals can be constructed (e.g. [3–15]). Here, we focus on the so-called doubly hybrid density functionals (DHDFs).

Section2.Heading: The MC3BB Type
Section2.Para:
Truhlar and co-workers coined, for the first time, the word ‘doubly hybrid’ and proposed the MC3BB method [12], where the conventional HF total energy and a scaled MP2 (second-order Møller-Plesset) correlation energy are mixed with the DFT (density functional theory) total energy as in Eq. 2.1. 2.1
$$ E_{\rm{tot}}^{\rm MC3BB} = e_{2} \left( {E_{\rm{tot}}^{\rm HF} + e_{1} E_{c}^{\rm MP2} } \right) + \left( {1 - e_{2} } \right)E_{\rm{tot}}^{\rm{\rm BBX}} $$

Here the DFT part, BBX, uses Becke88 [16] as its exchange and Becke95 [17] as its correlation, while X stands for the percentage of the HF-like exchange [18, 19]. The BBX functional adopts a form of one-mixing-parameter hybrid as in Eq. 1.70
. The MP2 correlation energy is calculated using the HF orbitals
$$ \left\{ {\phi_{i,a} } \right\} $$ with eigenvalues
$$ \left\{ {\varepsilon_{i,a} } \right\} $$ , 2.2
$$ E_{c}^{\rm MP2} = \frac{1}{4}\sum\limits_{ij}^{occ} {\sum\limits_{ab}^{vir} {\frac{{\left| {\left\langle {\phi_{i} \phi_{j} } \right|\left| {\phi_{a} \phi_{b} } \right\rangle } \right|^{2} }}{{\varepsilon_{i} + \varepsilon_{j} - \varepsilon_{a} - \varepsilon_{b} }}} } $$ where the subscripts (i, j) and (a, b) denote the occupied and virtual (unoccupied) HF orbitals, respectively.
$$\left\langle {\phi _{i} \phi _{j} \left\| {\phi _{a} \phi _{b} } \right.} \right\rangle = \left\langle {\phi _{i} \phi _{j} \left| {\phi _{a} \phi _{b} } \right.} \right\rangle - \left\langle {\phi _{i} \phi _{j} \left| {\phi _{b} \phi _{a} } \right.} \right\rangle $$ is an antisymmetrized combination of the regular two-electron repulsion integrals 2.3
$$\left\langle {\left. {\phi _{i} \phi _{j} } \right|\phi _{a} \phi _{b} } \right\rangle = \int\!\!\!\int\!\! \phi _{i} ^{*} \left({\vec{r}_{1}}\right)\phi _{j} ^{*} \left( {\vec{r}_{2} } \right)r_{{12}}^{{ - 1}} \phi _{a} \left( {\vec{r}_{1} } \right)\phi _{b} \left( {\vec{r}_{2} } \right){\rm{d}}\vec{r}_{1} {\rm{d}}\vec{r}_{2} $$

The parameters
$$ \left\{ {e_{1} ,e_{2} ,X} \right\} = \left\{ {1.332,0.205,0.39} \right\} $$ were obtained by fitting against a set of 109 atomization energies and 42 barrier heights. These parameters are basis set specific. In particular, the MP2 correlation energy and the HF total energy in Eq. 2.1 should be evaluated at the basis set level of 6−31 + G(d,p) within the frozen core approximation as originally designed [12]. The recommended basis set for the BBX calculations is an augmented polarized triple-zeta basis set MG3S, which is the same as 6-311
$$ {+} $$ G(3d2f,2df,2p) for H-Si but improved for P-Ar and no diffuse functions on hydrogens [20, 21].

It has to be noted that while the DFT part in Eq. 2.1 uses the KS (Kohn-Sham) orbitals based on the xc functional of
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{BBX}} $$ , the MP2 part uses the HF orbitals. Therefore, there are two sets of densities associated with Eq. 2.1, which goes beyond the frame work of KS DFT [22]. By assuming that the HF density and orbitals are the same as those from DFT, one may view the multicoefficient method MC3BB in terms of exchange-correlation functional, i.e., change the expression for total energy as in Eq. 2.1 to that for exchange-correlation functional [23] 2.4
$$E_{{xc}}^{{MC3BB}} \left[ \rho \right] = f_{1} E_{x}^{{HF}} + \left( {1 - f_{1} } \right)E_{x}^{S} + f_{2} \Delta E_{x}^{B} + \left( {1 - e_{2} } \right)E_{c}^{{B95}} + e_{1} e_{2} E_{c}^{{MP2}} $$
where
$$ f_{1} = e_{2} + \left( {1 - e_{2} } \right)X = 0.515 $$ , and
$$ f_{2} = \left( {1 - f_{1} } \right) = 0.485 $$ . From Eq. 2.4, it can be seen that, in addition to the hybridization in the exchange part
$$ \left( {E_{x}^{\rm HF} ,E_{x}^{S} ,\Updelta E_{x}^{B} } \right) $$ , the correlation part is also a hybrid between
$$ E_{c}^{\rm B95} $$ and
$$ E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$ , i.e., doubly hybrid.

The name MC3 suggests that this is a multicoefficient method that contains three parameters. It is empirical with the purpose to generalize the originally wavefunction based multicoefficient methods to allow the mixing with the hybrid density functional methods in order to achieve a good compromise of accuracy, cost, and ease of use for practical calculations [12].

Section2.Heading: The B2PLYP Type
Section2.Para:
Grimme proposed a widely recognized DHDF B2PLYP [13]. It employs two parameters: one is to hybridize the HF exchange with the Becke88 exchange functional, while the other is to hybridize the MP2-like correlation with the LYP correlation functional [24]. 2.5
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{B2PLYP}} = a_{x} E_{x}^{\rm HF} + \left( {1 - a_{x} } \right)\left( {E_{x}^{S} + \Updelta E_{x}^{B} } \right) + a_{c} E_{c}^{\rm{LYP}} + \left( {1 - a_{c} } \right)E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$

The parameters
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} = \left\{ {0.53,0.73} \right\} $$ [13] were determined by a parameterization against heats of formation (HOFs) of the G2/97 set [25, 26].

Note that the orbitals and orbital eigenvalues used to evaluate each term, including
$$ E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$ , in Eq. 2.5 are from the self-consistent-filed (SCF) calculation based on the ansatz of the DFT part alone in B2PLYP. Therefore, Eq. 2.5 can be reformulated as 2.6
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{B2PLYP}} = E_{\rm xc,{\rm{SCF}}}^{\rm{DFA}} + \left( {1 - a_{c} } \right)E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$

The mere purpose of the generalized KS type of calculation with
$$ E_{xc,{\rm{SCF}}}^{\rm{DFA}} $$ , similar to the HF calculation in the standard MP2 theory, is to provide a reference state for the followed perturbation calculation. Unlike the HF ansatz, the DFT part,
$$ E_{\rm xc,{\rm{SCF}}}^{\rm{DFA}} $$ , used to generate the orbitals has already contained an a
c portion of the LYP correlation. Hence the MP2-like correlation in B2PLYP is scaled by a factor of (
$$ 1 - a_{c} $$ ). There is no intension with these orbitals to give a mimic of the ground state density of the real system. This again goes beyond the KS frame work. The theoretical foundation of the B2PLYP-type DHDFs was later provided by Savin and co-workers based on the multideterminant extension of the Kohn-Sham scheme (see Sect. 2.3.1) [15].

Section2.Heading: The XYG3 Type
Section2.Para:
Based on the adiabatic connection formalism [3, 18, 27–29], (see Sect. 2.2.2) and Görling–Levy coupling-constant perturbation expansion to the second order
$$ E_{c}^{\rm GL2} $$ [30] (see Sect. 2.4.2), a new type of DHDF, namely XYG3, was proposed, which takes the form as [14]: 2.7
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{XYG3}} \left[ \rho \right] = d_{1} E_{x}^{\rm HF} + \left( {1 - d_{1} } \right)E_{x}^{S} + d_{2} \Updelta E_{x}^{B} + \left( {1 - d_{3} } \right)E_{c}^{\rm{LYP}} + d_{3} E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$

The parameters
$$ \left\{ {d_{1} ,d_{2} ,d_{3} } \right\} = \left\{ {0.8033,0.2107,0.3211} \right\} $$ [14] were determined by a parameterization against HOFs of the G3/99 set [25, 26, 31].

XYG3 distinguishes itself from the other DHDFs by using B3LYP orbitals and orbital eigenvalues to evaluate each term in Eq. 2.7. In such a way, XYG3 also shares with B3LYP the kinetic energy
$$ T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , the Coulomb energy
$$ J\left[ \rho \right] $$ , and the external potential energy
$$ V_{\rm{ext}} \left[ \rho \right] $$ in the construction of its total energy. As B3LYP is one of the most successful DFAs, it would be reasonable to expect that B3LYP gives good density that approximates well the true ground state density. This, we believe, holds the key to the success of the XYG3-type DH functionals [14, 32–42].

We may therefore classify the DHDFs currently available into three groups according to which orbitals are used to evaluate the perturbative correlation energy. In Truhlar’s MC3BB [12], HF orbitals are used to compute the MP2 correlation energy, which is then mixed with total energy from a conventional hybrid meta-GGA as defined in Eq. 2.1. In the B2PLYP family of functionals [13], a truncated DFA method is used to generate orbitals and density, whose total energy is then augmented with a scaled MP2 term, evaluated by the as produced orbitals, to normalize with the DFT correlation. XYG3 uses B3LYP to generate density and orbitals, which provide a good approximation to the real density [14]. While the MC3BB type of functionals is purely empirical as a generalization of the multicoefficient method [12], the B2PLYP and the XYG3 types of functionals have their own theoretical bases [14, 15, 30, 37], respectively, which we will discuss in the following sections.

Section2.Heading: Levy Constrained Search Approach
Section2.Para: We start by introducing the “constrained search” approach of Levy [43], which provides a constructive view of Hohenberg-Kohn Theorems and Kohn-Sham scheme [22, 44].

Solving the Schrödinger equation (Eq. 1.1
) for ground state energy is equivalent to minimizing
$$ \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{H}} \right|} \right.\Uppsi } \right\rangle $$ over all normalized, antisymmetric N-particle wavefunctions [43]: 2.8
$$ E = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to N} \left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{H}} \right|} \Uppsi \right\rangle $$

This can be achieved in a two-step fashion: 2.9
$$ E=\mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\rho \to N} \left\{ \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho} \left\langle\Uppsi|{\hat{H}}| \Uppsi \right\rangle\right\} $$

In the first step, we consider all wavefunctions which yield a given density
$$ \rho $$ , and in the second step, we consider all allowed densities. The minimizing density is then the ground state density
$$ \rho_{0} $$ , which is just what has already been stated in Eq. 1.11
as the Hohenberg-Kohn theorems. Comparing Eqs. 2.9 and 1.11
, one arrives at a definition of functional
$$ E\left[ \rho \right] $$ : 2.10
$$ \begin{aligned} E\left[ \rho \right] &= \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{H}} \right|} \Uppsi \right\rangle \hfill \\ & = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{T} + \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|}\Uppsi \right\rangle + \int {\rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \upsilon_{\rm{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right){\rm d}\vec{r} \hfill \\ \end{aligned} $$

The last term in Eq. 2.10 has used the fact that
$$ \Uppsi $$ giving the same
$$ \rho $$ also gives the same
$$ \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{V}_{\rm{ext}} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi } \right\rangle $$ . Equation 2.10, in turn, as compared to Eq. 1.7
, defines the Hohenberg-Kohn functional
$$ F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] $$ : 2.11
$$ F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{T} + \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \Uppsi \right\rangle $$

For the Kohn-Sham system of noninteracting electrons,
$$ \hat{V}_{\rm ee} $$ vanishes so that
$$ F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] $$ reduces to 2.12
$$ T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{T}} \right|} \Uppsi \right\rangle = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Upphi \to \rho } \left\langle {\Upphi \left| {\hat{T}} \right|} \Upphi \right\rangle $$ where the N-particle wave function
$$ \Uppsi $$ is reduced to
$$ \Upphi $$ which corresponds to the single Slater determinant constructed from one-electron orbitals
$$ \left\{ {\phi_{i} } \right\} $$ (c.f. Eq. 1.16
).

Section2.Heading: Adiabatic Connection Formalism
Section2.Para:
The Hohenberg-Kohn theorems merely prove the existence of
$$ F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , which gives no direct guidance to the construction of the functional. The Kohn-Sham scheme pulls out the large part of the kinetic energy via
$$ T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] $$ , but still leaves the exact xc functional
$$ E_{\rm xc} \left[ \rho \right] $$ unknown. The adiabatic connection formalism [3, 18, 27–29] provides a possible route that
$$ E_{\rm xc} \left[ \rho \right] $$ can be pursued.

Let us define a Hamiltonian
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda } $$ that represents a set of systems in which the electron–electron interaction is scaled [3, 18, 27–29] 2.13
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda } = \hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} + \hat{V}_{\lambda } $$

The one-electron potential
$$ \hat{V}_{\lambda } = \sum\nolimits_{i = 1}^{N} {\upsilon_{\lambda } \left( {\left[ \rho \right];\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} $$ is also scaled simultaneously so that a prescribed density
$$ \rho $$ is fixed independent of
$$ \lambda $$ . This sets up the so-called adiabatic connection path along
$$ \lambda $$ . Then
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda = 0} = \hat{T} + \hat{V}_{s} $$ is for the Kohn-Sham system, and
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda = 1} = \hat{T} + \hat{V}_{\rm ee} + \hat{V}_{\rm{ext}} $$ is for the real system. This suggests: 2.14
$$ \hat{V}_{\lambda = 0} = \hat{V}_{s} \,\text{and}\,\hat{V}_{\lambda = 1} = \hat{V}_{\rm{ext}} $$

For any allowed
$$ \Uppsi $$ , we have 2.15
$$ E_{\lambda } = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{H}_{\lambda } } \right|\Uppsi } \right\rangle = \left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left| {\hat{H}_{\lambda } } \right|\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle $$

Here we use
$$ \Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } $$ to indicate a variational solution of Eq. 2.15 that yields density
$$ \rho $$ . Clearly,
$$ \Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } $$ is also the wavefunction that minimizes the expectation value of
$$ \left( {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right) $$ : 2.16
$$ F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi } \right\rangle = \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle $$ which defines a generalized HK functional
$$ F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ .

Hellman-Feynman theorem tells us [3, 45, 46] 2.17
$$ \frac{{dE_{\lambda } }}{d\lambda } = \left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\frac{{\partial \hat{H}_{\lambda } }}{\partial \lambda }} \right.} \right|\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle $$

Inserting Eq. (2.13) into Eq. (2.17) and integrating it from
$$ \lambda \, = \, 0 $$ to
$$ \lambda \, = \, 1 $$ , we have 2.18
$$\int_{0}^{1} {\left( {\frac{{dE_{\lambda } }}{{d\lambda }}} \right)} d\lambda = \int_{0}^{1} {\left\langle {\Psi _{\lambda }^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\frac{{\partial \left( {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{{ee}} } \right)}}{{\partial \lambda }}} \right.} \right|\Psi _{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle } {\rm{d}}\lambda + \int_{0}^{1} {\left\langle {\Psi _{\lambda }^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\frac{{\partial \hat{V}_{\lambda } }}{{\partial \lambda }}} \right.} \right|\Psi _{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle } {\rm{d}}\lambda $$

Hence, 2.19
$$ \left( {E_{\lambda = 1} - E_{\lambda = 0} } \right) = \int\limits_{0}^{1} {\left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right.} \right|\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle } \rm d\lambda + \left( {V_{\lambda = 1} - V_{\lambda = 0} } \right) $$

In getting the second term on the right-hand side of Eq. 2.19, we have taken advantage of the assumption that the electron density is held fixed along the adiabatic path from
$$ \lambda \, = \, 0 $$ to
$$ \lambda \, = \, 1 $$ . Inserting Eqs. 1.7
, 1.18
, 1.20
, and 2.14 into Eq. 2.19, we have 2.20
$$E_{{xc}} \left[ \rho \right] = \int_{0}^{1} {\left\langle {\Psi _{\lambda }^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\hat{V}_{{ee}} } \right.} \right|\Psi _{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle } d\lambda - J\left[ \rho \right]$$

This actually defines the exchange-correlation energy in terms of the coupling-constant integration [3, 27–29, 47–49] 2.21
$$ E_{\rm xc} \left[ \rho \right] = \int\limits_{0}^{1} {W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right]} \rm d\lambda $$ where 2.22
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right.} \right|\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle - J\left[ \rho \right] $$

From Eq. 2.22, it is immediate to see that
$$ W_{0} \left[ \rho \right] $$ is nothing but the exchange energy of the KS determinant 2.23
$$ W_{0} \left[ \rho \right] = \left\langle {\Upphi^{\rho } \left. {\left| {\hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right.} \right|\Upphi^{\rho } } \right\rangle - J\left[ \rho \right] = E_{x}^{\rm HF} $$

Section1.Heading: Rationale of DHDFs of the B2PLYP Type

Section2.Heading: Multideterminant Extension of the Kohn-Sham Scheme
Section2.Para:
We start by reformulating the total energy
$$ E_{\rm tot} $$ for the physical system, given in Eq. 1.7
, in terms of the generalized HK functional 2.24
$$ E\left[ \rho \right] = F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] + V_{\rm{ext}} \left[ \rho \right] + \bar{E}_{\rm{Hxc}}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$

$$ \bar{E}_{\rm Hxc}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] - F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ is the complement HK functional [43, 50, 51], which can be further developed in related to the KS system: 2.25
$$ \bar{E}_{\rm{Hxc}}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \left( {F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] - T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]} \right) - \left( {F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] - T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]} \right) $$ where the first term in the right-hand side is
$$ J\left[ \rho \right] + E_{\rm xc} \left[ \rho \right] $$ (see Eq. 1.20
), while the second term is given by
$$ \left( {F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] - T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]} \right) = \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle - \left. {\left\langle {\Upphi^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T}} \right|} \right.\Upphi^{\rho } } \right\rangle $$ . Hence [43, 50, 51] 2.26
$$ \bar{E}_{\rm{Hxc}}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \left( {1 - \lambda } \right)J\left[ \rho \right] + \left( {1 - \lambda } \right)E_{x} \left[ \rho \right] + \left( {E_{c} \left[ \rho \right] - E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right]} \right) $$

Here
$$ E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ is defined as [43, 46] 2.27
$$ E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle - \left. {\left\langle {\Upphi^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Upphi^{\rho } } \right\rangle $$ which corresponds to the correlation energy of a partial interacting system. Under uniform scaling of the density
$$ \left[ {\rho_{\gamma } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \gamma^{3} \rho \left( {\gamma \vec{r}} \right)} \right],\gamma = {1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 \lambda }} \right. \kern-0pt} \lambda } $$ [46, 52–55], 2.28
$$ E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \lambda^{2} E_{c} \left[ {\rho_{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 \lambda }} \right. \kern-0pt} \lambda }}} } \right] $$
2.29
$$ E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] \approx \lambda^{2} E_{c} \left[ \rho \right] $$

Equation 2.29 is an approximation where density scaling is neglected
$$ E_{c} \left[ {\rho_{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 \lambda }} \right. \kern-0pt} \lambda }}} } \right] \approx E_{c} \left[ \rho \right] $$ [15].
$$ \bar{E}_{\rm Hxc}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ is also called the complement
$$ \lambda $$ -dependent Hartree-exchange-correlation density functional [15].

Equation 2.24 requires to carry out minimization over all allowed
$$ \Uppsi $$ , which is, however, impractical, due to the existence of
$$ \hat{V}_{\rm ee} $$ that leads to
$$ \Uppsi $$ of a general multideterminant character [15, 43]: 2.30
$$ E_{\rm{tot}} = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Uppsi \to \rho } \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi } \right\rangle + V_{\rm{ext}} \left[ \rho \right] + \bar{E}_{\rm{Hxc}}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$

A density-scaled one-parameter hybrid (DS1H) approximation [15] is then defined by restricting the minimization in Eq. 2.30 to single-determinant wavefunction Φ: 2.31
$$ E^{\rm{DS1H},\lambda } = \mathop {\hbox{min} }\limits_{\Upphi } \left. {\left\langle {\Upphi \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Upphi } \right\rangle + V_{\rm{ext}} \left[ {\rho_{\Upphi } } \right] + \bar{E}_{\rm{Hxc}}^{\lambda } \left[ {\rho_{\Upphi } } \right] $$

This is equivalent to solving the HF problem. The single-particle equations are: 2.32
$$ \begin{array} {ll}\left[ { - \frac{1}{2}\nabla^{2} + \upsilon_{\rm{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \upsilon_{J} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \lambda \upsilon_{x}^{\rm HF} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \left( {1 - \lambda } \right)\upsilon_{x} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \right. \hfill \\ \left. { + \upsilon_{c} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) - \frac{{\delta E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}}} \right]\phi_{i}^{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \varepsilon_{i}^{\lambda } \phi_{i}^{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) \hfill \\ \end{array} $$

If Eq. 2.29 is adopted, Eq. 2.32 is simplified as 2.33
$$ \begin{array}{ll} \left[ { - \frac{1}{2}\nabla^{2} + \upsilon_{\rm{ext}} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \upsilon_{J} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \lambda \upsilon_{x}^{\rm HF} \left( {\vec{r}} \right) + \left( {1 - \lambda } \right)\upsilon_{x} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \right. \hfill \\ \left. {+ \left( {1 - \lambda^{2} } \right)\upsilon_{c} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)} \right]\phi_{i}^{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \varepsilon_{i}^{\lambda } \phi_{i}^{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) \hfill \\ \end{array} $$ which corresponds to the so-called 1H approximation without considering density scaling [15]. The final DS1H and 1H energies are then given, respectively, by 2.34
$$ \begin{aligned} E_{\rm{SCF}}^{\rm{DS1H},\lambda } = & - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\int {\left( {\phi_{i}^{\lambda } } \right)^{*} \nabla^{2} \phi_{i}^{\lambda } {\rm d}\vec{r}} } + V_{\rm{ext}} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] + J\left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] + \lambda E_{x}^{HF} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] \hfill \\ & + \left( {1 - \lambda } \right)E_{x} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] + E_{c} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] - E_{c}^{\lambda } \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] \hfill \\ \end{aligned} $$
2.35
$$ \begin{aligned} E_{\rm{SCF}}^{1H,\lambda } = & - \frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\int {\left( {\phi_{i}^{\lambda } } \right)^{*} \nabla^{2} \phi_{i}^{\lambda } d\vec{r}} } + V_{\rm{ext}} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] + J\left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] + \lambda E_{x}^{\rm HF} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] \hfill \\ & + \left( {1 - \lambda } \right)E_{x} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] + \left( {1 - \lambda^{2} } \right)E_{c} \left[ {\rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} } \right] \hfill \\ \end{aligned} $$

Equation 2.35 has a similar form for its
$$ E_{\rm xc} $$ as that in the standard one-parameter hybrid functionals (c.f. Eq. 1.70
) such as B1LYP or PBE0 [28, 56]. One salient difference, however, is that the correlation energy is weighted by
$$ \left( {1 - \lambda^{2} } \right) $$ while in the standard one-parameter hybrid functionals it is weighted by a factor of 1. Due to the scaled interaction
$$ \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} $$ , only partial correlation energy is contained in Eqs. 2.34 and 2.35. The missing part can be repaired by a nonlinear Rayleigh-Schrödinger perturbation theory [57] staring from the DS1H or 1H reference. Just like in standard Moller-Plesset perturbation theory, the final energy up to second order is given by [15]: 2.36
$$ E^{\rm{DS1DH},\lambda } = E_{\rm{SCF}}^{\rm{DS1H},\lambda } + \lambda^{2} E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$
2.37
$$ E^{\rm 1DH,\lambda } = E_{\rm{SCF}}^{\rm 1H,\lambda } + \lambda^{2} E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$

This provides a rationale for DHDFs of the B2PLYP type. One has to note that, just like the HF theory whose density is by definition not the ground state density of the real system,
$$ \rho_{{\Upphi^{\lambda } }} $$ by construction is not meant to be the ground state density of the real system. From Eq. 2.30 to 2.31, one starts from the adiabatic connection formulism, but eventually departs from the adiabatic connection path by replacing the general multideterminant
$$ \Uppsi $$ with a single-determinant wavefunction Φ with no constraint on the density
$$ \rho $$ .

Section2.Heading: Development of DHDFs of the B2PLYP Type
Section2.Para:
B2PLYP was proposed before DS1DH and 1DH. The later explored the theoretical foundation of the B2PLYP-type DHDFs in terms of multideterminant extension of the Kohn-Sham scheme. On the other hand, as Eq. 2.29 is just an approximation, the scaling factor before
$$ E_{c} \left[ \rho \right] $$ needs not to be
$$ \lambda^{2} $$ . Hence
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} $$ in B2PLYP can be optimized independently. In fact, B2PLYP was originally understood as an interpolation approach between pure GGA-DFT and MP2, respectively [13]. As seen from Eq. 2.5, if
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} = \left\{ {1.0,0.0} \right\} $$ , MP2 is recovered, while if
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} = \left\{ {0.0,1.0} \right\} $$ , B2PLYP is reduced to BLYP. Furthermore, if
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} = \left\{ {0.0,0.0} \right\} $$ (i.e., B-MP2), an exchange-only SCF calculation may be first performed, whose orbitals and orbital eigenvalues are then used to get the MP2 energy. If
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} = \left\{ {1.0,1.0} \right\} $$ (i.e., HF-LYP), the full portion of nonlocal HF exchange is in company with the semilocal LYP correlation energy.

As typical DFT correlation functionals are superior to MP2 in the description of short-range correlation, and MP2 is very well suited for the description of long-range correlation, it was therefore expected that the doubly hybrid functionals that combine the two should handle both types of correlation better than either conventional DFTs and MP2 [13]. On the other hand, there are areas characterized by some physically inappropriate combination of
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} $$ which leads to, e.g., unbalanced treatment of dynamical and static correlation effects [13, 58]. Hence,
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} $$ should be optimized.

Along this line, several new functionals of the B2PLYP type (e.g., B2T-PLYP [59], B2K-PLYP [58, 59], B2GP-PLYP [58], B2
$$\pi$$ -PLYP [23], ROB2-PLYP [60], UB2-PLYP [60], ωB97X-2 [61] etc.) have been developed. While
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} $$ in B2T-PLYP are optimized against some thermodynamic data, those in B2K-PLYP are optimized against some kinetic data [59]. For a chemical reaction, the forward and backward reaction barrier heights are connected through the reaction thermodynamics. Hence, there is a need for some functionals to be of general purpose (e.g., B2GP-PLYP) [58]. The B2
$$\pi$$ -PLYP functional was optimized specially for π-conjugated systems [23]. ROB2-PLYP and UB2PLYP recognize the importance to distinguish a restricted and an unrestricted calculation for open shell systems [60]. The ωB97X-2 [61] functional can also be put into the B2PLYP class where the truncated DFT is a long-range corrected hybrid of the B97 [62] type.

Figure 2.1 illustrates the area of
$$ \left\{ {a_{x} ,a_{c} } \right\} $$ where the B2PLYP family of functionals based on BLYP work best for certain properties. More recently, other GGA and meta-GGA functionals have come into play [13, 59, 64]. Not only the mixing parameters, but also the parameters within GGAs and meta-GGAs are refitted to optimize the final performance of DHDFs [64]. These GGAs or meta-GGAs cannot be used alone, as their mere purpose is to provide a reference state where the scaled MP2 correction can be evaluated. Furthermore, as the MP2 term contains the same-spin and opposite spin components, spin-component scaled DHDFs have been introduced [65, 66].
Fig. 2.1
The B2PLYP family of functionals based on BLYP [76]

Conventional DFAs miss the
$$ R^{ - 6} $$ decay behavior in the long-range correlation [67], and hence fail badly for dispersion-dominant nonbonded interactions. The delocalized
$$ E_{c}^{\rm MP2} $$ captures the correct long-range behavior by construction. However, a global fraction (~30 %) of the MP2 correlation is incomplete to describe the full correlation effect in the long range [68]. It was therefore suggested to add the functionals a posterior force field (FF) like dispersion correction (-D or -D3) [69–71] to impose the correct long-range
$$ R^{ - 6} $$ interatomic dependence. More recently, the DFT-D or DFT-D3 method was made an integrated method where the parameters in the corresponding DFA (i.e., electronic) part were optimized in conjunction with the optimization of the parameters in the FF-like dispersion correction terms, in a hope that the medium- to long-range correlations were completely took over by the classic FF terms, and not mimicked by the DFA part to avoid double-counting [64, 66]. While such DFT-D or -D3 scheme can be implemented efficiently without additional computational cost, it includes many empirical parameters, and suffers from some inherent limitations [69, 72]. Especially, the many-body correlation effects and anisotropy effects in the long-range dispersive interactions, as well as the orbital-dependence in the medium range [72, 73], are more subtle, which are difficult to be approximated in the pair-wise additive FF models.

Detailed benchmark calculations of the B2PLYP-type functionals can be found in the literature [64]. Some of the key findings are represented in Chap. 3
.

Section1.Heading: Rationale of DHDFs of the XYG3 Type

Section2.Heading: Becke’s Hybrid-DFT Methods
Section2.Para:
In Sect. 1.2.5
, we have tried to motivate Becke’s hybrid-DFT methods from a view for a balanced treatment of static and dynamic correlations [74]. In fact, adiabatic connection formalism [3, 18, 27–29] provides a better way to comprehend these methods [18, 19, 75].

It is true that the main problem or challenge of the adiabatic connection approach for functional construction by using Eq. 2.21 is that the exact integrand
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ is unknown. The optimistic picture is that while
$$ \Uppsi \left( {\vec{r}_{1} \sigma_{1} , \ldots ,\vec{r}_{N} \sigma_{N} } \right) $$ to be solved in the Schrödinger equation is of 4 N dimension, the divine xc functional
$$ E_{\rm xc} \left[ \rho \right] $$ characterized by
$$ \rho $$ is only 3-dimensional. Hence, the problem is simplified. Within the adiabatic connection approach, one can then focus on the
$$ \lambda $$ space of 1-dimension to approximate
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ by a model function of
$$ \lambda $$ . This may seem to be an even ‘easier’ task. In fact, this scenario has been explored for functional construction by several researchers [18, 19, 28, 29].

Becke assumed a linear model for
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ [18]: 2.38
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = a\left[ \rho \right] + b\left[ \rho \right]\lambda $$

Integrating Eq. 2.21 by using Eq. 2.38 leads to an energy expression 2.39
$$ E_{\rm xc} \left[ \rho \right] = a + \frac{1}{2}b $$

From Eq. 2.38, it is obvious that 2.40
$$ a = W_{0} \left[ \rho \right];\,b = W_{1} \left[ \rho \right] - W_{0} \left[ \rho \right] $$

While
$$ W_{0} \left[ \rho \right] $$ is just the HF exchange (Eq. 2.23),
$$ W_{1} \left[ \rho \right] $$ corresponds to the potential energy contribution to the xc energy of the fully interacting system, which is yet unknown. Originally, Becke used a LDA to approximate
$$ W_{1} \left[ \rho \right] $$ [18]: 2.41
$$ W_{1} \left[ \rho \right] \approx W_{\rm xc}^{\rm LDA} = E_{x}^{\rm LDA} + W_{c}^{\rm LDA} $$

Nevertheless, it is quite common to approximate
$$ W_{c}^{\rm{LDA}} $$ with
$$ E_{c}^{\rm{LDA}} $$ or
$$ \frac{1}{2}W_{c}^{\rm{LDA}} $$ with
$$ E_{c}^{\rm{GGA}} $$ such as
$$ E_{c}^{\rm{LYP}} $$ , leading to 2.42
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{BHandH}} \left[ \rho \right] = \frac{1}{2}\left( {E_{x}^{\rm HF} + E_{x}^{S} } \right) +\frac{1}{2} \,E_{c}^{\rm{LYP}} $$
2.43
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{BHandHLYP}} \left[ \rho \right] = \frac{1}{2}\left( {E_{x}^{\rm HF} + E_{x}^{B} } \right) + E_{c}^{\rm{LYP}} $$

Equation 2.42 corresponds to the so-called BHandH functional, while Eq. 2.43 stands for the so-called BHandHLYP functional as implemented in Gaussian suite of program [76]. Mixing in some portion of the HF exchange results in a significant improvement in functional performance for covalent bonded systems over (semi)local functionals. The take-home message from Eq. 2.43 is that the source of errors shall be traced back to the improper behavior of (semi) local exchange functionals at the
$$ \lambda \to 0 $$ limit [18]. Within this linear model, half of the (semi)local exchange should be replaced by half of the HF exchange.

Section2.Heading: Coupling-Constant Expansion
Section2.Para:
Let us start by reformulating the Hamiltonian
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda } $$ (Eq. 2.13) of the partially interacting system with respect to the Hamiltonian
$$ \hat{H}_{s} $$ ( 1.14
) of the noninteracting KS system 2.44
$$ \begin{aligned} \hat{H}_{\lambda } &= \hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} + \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\upsilon_{\lambda } \left( {\left[ \rho \right];\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} \hfill \\ & = \left( {\hat{T} + \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\upsilon_{s} \left( {\left[ \rho \right];\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} } \right) + \lambda H^{\prime} \hfill \\ \end{aligned} $$

In writing Eq. 2.44, we have emphasized the fact that density is fixed to be
$$ \rho $$ for any
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda } $$ of varying
$$ \lambda $$ . Equation 2.44 defines the perturbation 2.45
$$ \hat{H}^{\prime} = \hat{V}_{\rm ee} + \frac{1}{\lambda }\sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\left[ {\upsilon_{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right) - \upsilon_{s} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} \right]} $$

According to the standard perturbation theory [30, 54], the ground state energy associated with
$$ \hat{H}_{\lambda } $$ can be written down as: 2.46
$$ E_{\lambda } = E_{s}^{0} + \lambda E^{\left( 1 \right)} + \lambda^{2} E^{\left( 2 \right)} + \lambda^{3} E^{\left( 3 \right)} + O\left( {\lambda^{4} } \right) $$ where
$$ E_{s}^{0} $$ corresponds to the ground state energy associated with
$$ \hat{H}_{s} $$ , and
$$ E^{\left( k \right)} $$ refers to the kth-order energy correction to
$$ E_{s}^{0} $$ . Here, we have assumed that
$$ \hat{H}_{s} $$ has a nondegenerate ground state
$$ \Upphi_{s}^{0} = \Upphi^{\rho } $$ with other eigenstates
$$ \Upphi_{s}^{m} $$ of eigenvalues
$$ E_{s}^{m} \left( {m \ne 0} \right) $$ . Hence, 2.47
$$ E_{s}^{0} = \left\langle {\Upphi_{s}^{0} } \right|\hat{H}_{s} \left| {\Upphi_{s}^{0} } \right\rangle $$
2.48
$$ E^{\left( 1 \right)} = \left\langle {\Upphi_{s}^{0} } \right|\hat{H}^{\prime}\left| {\Upphi_{s}^{0} } \right\rangle $$
2.49
$$ E^{\left( 2 \right)} = \sum\limits_{m \ne 0}^{\infty } {\frac{{\left| {\left\langle {\Uppsi_{s}^{0} } \right|\hat{H}^{\prime}\left| {\Uppsi_{s}^{m} } \right\rangle } \right|^{2} }}{{E_{s}^{0} - E_{s}^{m} }}} $$

In order to keep the density ρ constant for all values of the coupling constant
$$ \lambda \, = \, 0 \to 1 $$ , it is required that the chemical potential μ should be constant for this family of partially interacting N-electron systems. As the generalized HK functional is given by 2.51
$$ \begin{gathered} F_{\rm HK}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = F_{\rm HK} \left[ \rho \right] - \bar{E}_{\rm Hxc}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] \hfill \\ \,\,\,\, = T_{s} \left[ \rho \right] + \lambda J\left[ \rho \right] + \lambda E_{x} \left[ \rho \right] + \lambda^{2} E_{c} \left[ {\rho_{1/ \lambda }} \right] \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$ the corresponding Euler-Lagrange equation (c.f. Eqs. 1.13
and 1.21
) becomes 2.52
$$ \mu = \frac{{\delta F_{{HK}}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} + \upsilon _{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}} \right) = \frac{{\delta T_{s} \left[ \rho \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}} \right)}} + \upsilon _{s} \left( {\vec{r}} \right)$$ giving 2.53
$$\left( {\upsilon _{\lambda } \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right) - \upsilon _{s} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} \right) = - \lambda \left[ {\upsilon _{J} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right) + \upsilon _{x} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right) + \lambda \frac{{\delta E_{c} \left[ {\rho _{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 \lambda }} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} \lambda }}} } \right]}}{{\delta \rho \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right)}}} \right]$$

Hence
$$ \hat{H^{\prime}} $$ in Eq. 2.45 can be simplified for
$$ \lambda \to 0 $$ as [30]: 2.54
$$ \Updelta = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{\lambda \to 0} \hat{H^{\prime}} = \hat{V}_{\rm ee} - \sum\limits_{i = 1}^{N} {\left[ {\upsilon_{J} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right) + \upsilon_{x} \left( {\vec{r}_{i} } \right)} \right]} $$

Inserting Eq. 2.54 into Eq. 2.50, we arrive at a perturbation description of
$$ E_{c} \left[{\rho_{1/\lambda}} \right] $$ : 2.55
$$ \mathop {\lim }\limits_{{\lambda \to 0}} E_{c} \left[ {\rho _{{{1 \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {1 \lambda }} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} \lambda }}} } \right] = E^{{(2)}} $$ where as a weak perturbation, Eq. 2.49 is simplified as 2.56
$$ E^{\left( 2 \right)} = \sum\limits_{m \ne 0}^{\infty } {\frac{{\left| {\left\langle {\Upphi_{s}^{0} } \right|\Updelta \left| {\Upphi_{s}^{m} } \right\rangle } \right|^{2} }}{{E_{s}^{0} - E_{s}^{m} }}} $$

$$ E^{\left( 2 \right)} $$ is widely recognized as the Görling–Levy theory of coupling-constant perturbation expansion to the second order, which may be explicitly written in terms of KS orbitals as [30] 2.57
$$ E^{(2)} = E_{c}^{\rm GL2} = \sum\limits_{i}^{occ} {\sum\limits_{a}^{vir} {\frac{{\left| {\left\langle {\phi_{i} } \right|\upsilon_{x} - \upsilon_{x}^{\rm HF} \left| {\phi_{a} } \right\rangle } \right|^{2} }}{{\varepsilon_{i} - \varepsilon_{a} }}} } + \frac{1}{4}\sum\limits_{ij}^{occ} {\sum\limits_{ab}^{vir} {\frac{{\left| {\left\langle {\phi_{i} \phi_{j} } \right|\left| {\phi_{a} \phi_{b} } \right\rangle } \right|^{2} }}{{\varepsilon_{i} + \varepsilon_{j} - \varepsilon_{a} - \varepsilon_{b} }}} } $$

Equation 2.57 should be compared with Eq. 2.2 for MP2. In addition to the difference in the meaning of orbitals, i.e., HF orbitals in MP2 and KS orbitals in GL2, there is an additional term from singles’ contributions [30].

Section2.Heading: Development of DHDFs of the XYG3 Type
Section2.Para: Based on the adiabatic connection formalism [3, 18, 27–29] and Görling–Levy coupling-constant perturbation expansion [30] to the second order, we proposed XYG3 [14].

For a partially interacting system, the xc functional may be defined as 2.58
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = \left. {\left\langle {\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T} + \lambda \hat{V}_{\rm ee} } \right|} \right.\Uppsi_{\lambda }^{\rho } } \right\rangle - \left. {\left\langle {\Upphi^{\rho } \left| {\hat{T}} \right|} \right.\Upphi^{\rho } } \right\rangle - \lambda J\left[ \rho \right] $$ which can be reformulated as 2.59
$$ \begin{gathered} E_{\rm xc}^{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] =\, \lambda E_{x}^{\rm HF} \left[ \rho \right] + \lambda^{2} E_{c} \left[ {\rho_ {1 /\lambda }} \right] \hfill \\ \,\,\,\; = \lambda E_{x}^{\rm HF} \left[ \rho \right] + \lambda^{2} E^{(2)} + O\left( {\lambda^{3} } \right) \hfill \\ \,\,\,\; = \int_{0}^{\lambda } {W_{{\lambda^{\prime}}} } \left[ \rho \right]d\lambda^{\prime} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$

Hence, for weak perturbation, we have 2.60
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] = E_{x}^{\rm HF} \left[ \rho \right] + 2\lambda E_{c}^{\rm GL2} + O\left( {\lambda^{2} } \right) $$

Equation 2.60 provides a formula with which
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ can be approximated. As compared with Eq. 2.38 for the linear model (Fig. 2.2), it is clear, instead of choosing the initial point and the ending point of
$$ \{ W_{0} ,\,W_{1} \} $$ but approximating
$$ W_{1} \approx W_{\rm xc}^{\rm LDA} $$ as Becke did in his half and half functional [18], parameters
$$ \left\{ {a,\,b} \right\} $$ in Eq. 2.39 can be rigorously fixed using {
$$ W_{0} $$ ,
$$ W^{\prime}_{0} $$ } [14]:
Fig. 2.2
Linear (a) or nonlinear (b) model for adiabatic connection path [79]
2.62
$$ a = E_{x}^{\rm HF} ; \; b = 2E_{c}^{\rm GL2} $$

This provides an exact functional in terms of KS orbitals, if the linear dependence of
$$ W_{\lambda } \left[ \rho \right] $$ on
$$ \lambda $$ is faithfully fulfilled. 2.63
$$ E_{\rm xc}^{\rm linearAC} = E_{x}^{\rm HF} + E_{c}^{\rm GL2} $$

Equation 2.63 may look similar to the standard MP2 theory where the HF exchange is augmented with the MP2 correlation. It has to be emphasized that the MP2 method is just the lowest level correlated wavefunction method for many electron systems, whereas Eq. 2.63 is exact for any system with linear
$$ \lambda $$ -dependence.

To go beyond the linear model, we proposed to choose b as in Eq. 2.64, where
$$ \left\{ {b_{1} ,b_{2} } \right\} $$ are empirical parameters introduced here to optimize the functional performance [14]: 2.64
$$ b = b_{1} E_{c}^{\rm GL2} + b_{2} \left( {E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{DFT}} - E_{x}^{\rm HF} } \right) $$

Assuming that
$$ E_{c}^{\rm{DFA}} \approx \left( {E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{DFA}} - E_{x}^{\rm HF} } \right) $$ contains a complete description of correlation effects, the second term of Eq. 2.64 may also be viewed as a way to extrapolate the second-order perturbation to infinite order to account for the higher order,
$$ O\left( {\lambda^{2} } \right) $$ in Eq. 2.60 dependence of
$$ W_{\lambda } $$ on
$$ \lambda $$ .

In analogy to the B3 scheme shown in Eq. 1.71
, we proposed a new type of DHDFs which read as [14, 37] 2.65
$$ \begin{gathered} E_{\rm xc}^{\rm{xDH}} \left[ \rho \right] = a_{0} E_{x}^{\rm HF} + \left( {1 - a_{0} } \right)E_{x}^{\rm{LDA}} + a_{x} \Updelta E_{x}^{\rm{GGA}} \hfill \\ \,\,\,\,\,\,\; + a_{1} E_{c}^{\rm GL2} + \left( {1 - a_{1} } \right)E_{c}^{\rm{LDA}} + a_{c} \Updelta E_{c}^{\rm{GGA}} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$

Here
$$ E_{x}^{\rm{GGA}} \left[ \rho \right] = E_{x}^{\rm{LDA}} + \Updelta E_{x}^{\rm{GGA}} ,E_{c}^{\rm{GGA}} \left[ \rho \right] = E_{c}^{\rm LDA} + \Updelta E_{c}^{\rm{GGA}} $$ . Of course, the GGA functional can be replaced by a meta-GGA functional. Equation 2.65 suggests that not only some portion of the (semi) local exchange functional be substituted by the HF exchange, but also some portion of the (semi)local correlation functional be substituted by the GL2 correlation. While it is important to properly describe the initial value of
$$ W_{\lambda } $$ with
$$ E_{x}^{\rm HF} $$ , it is also essential to accurately describe the initial slope of
$$ W_{\lambda } $$ with
$$ E_{c}^{\rm GL2} $$ .

In setting up the first xDH functional XYG3 (Eq. 2.7), we have adopted LDA = SVWN [80, 81] and GGA = BLYP [16, 24]. As the LYP functional does not reduce to the correct limit for a uniform electron gas by construction, we have constrained
$$ \left( {1 - a_{1} } \right) = a_{c} $$ , which practically eliminated one fitting parameter.

Note that single-excitation contribution is also not explicitly calculated in XYG3, such that the GL2 term [30] is actually approximated by the MP2-like PT2 term. We have argued that the singles contribution can be absorbed into
$$ E_{c}^{\rm{DFA}} $$ and the fitting parameters against the experimental data [14].

Unlike in LDAs and GGAs, where the xc energy is represented by an explicit functional of the density, DHDFs are formally orbital-dependent functionals which are implicit functionals of the electron density [12, 14]. The so-called optimized effective potential (OEP) method [82–86] should be invoked where the variational optimization of the energy associated with DHDFs should be carried out under the additional constraint of a local xc potential. It is interesting to note that the kinetic energy of the KS system has already been represented by an orbital-dependent functional, while the HF exchange is another evident orbital-dependent functional. Here, we again make a detour to avoid OEP by using the well-established B3LYP to provide the orbital information required for the construction of energy terms in XYG3. We believe that other fully functionalized DFAs (i.e., nontruncated) can play a similar role as B3LYP does in XYG3. In particular, pure GGAs with local multiplicative potentials are in better accordance with Görling–Levy coupling-constant perturbation expansion theory [30].
